I can't wait to see what happens with this game down the line but you better believe I'm going to be watching for a long time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, how do you go about reviewing an Early Access Game?
I think the best way is to measure the improvements to the game over a course of a few weeks.

When I bought the gameIt was little more than a tech demo with a lot of bugs. It only had 3 or so ressources, awkward villager management and not many things to build. I was constantly overrun by zombies, there was little balancing.

Now that I´m writing this reviewOver the past weeks the game has been updated on a regular basis, bugs fixed and content added. The community is being involved in the developement process.
The game has a much more differentiated interface and villager statistics. A ressource refinement system has been added, the magic ressource 'crystal' is now usable and powers some of your buildings. The balancing has improved a lot in a way that you actually have a chance to survive. Monsters have been added and others balanced. Most of the ressources are renewable now. You can already call it a game at this point, it is playable up to end-game without major disruptions in the gameplay.

What to expect from this gameYou get an indie survival game with tower defense as well as rpg elements. Build up your medieval fantasy village and try to survive the neverending undead onslaught.

Still being early access, the game has a lot of potential to go in many directions.
More towers could be added, like electric or acid, dealing splash/aoe damage, or to target specific monsters with weaknesses to certain damage types.
A crafting system could be added to bring out the rpg side, allowing armor and weapons, or a profession system like warriors, mages, archers.

What I´d really like to see are more maps. Maybe a community map contest?

PricingAt the current stage, being in early access, I find the price a bit high, since the user doesn´t get the finished game yet. In my opinion early access games should reward buying it/taking the risk in this stage.
If the game continues on it´s path the price will be justified for the final release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A magnificent attention to detail went into the textures for this game! With several variations for each object or tile, nothing in the map looks quite like the copy-and-paste wireframe you usually expect to see in other 2D pixel games. Down to the last blade of grass, there seems to be a nice variety of different shades, shapes and directions each individual block displays - with every texture having a decorative secondary layer for its own material type. Complementing the game's surprisingly vibrant and lively textures is an amazing, hand-crafted lighting system ruled over by some of the other textures and objects, and a fully functional day-and-night cycle. Torches provide a light source, lava illuminates a small radius of land around it, and crystals glow in the dark like fireflies. Every wall and object has a dynamic and intricate reaction to which direction the sun is in relation to the world below (as well as other light sources), which changes gradually as the day cycle goes by. Even the water shines in the night as the moon reflects down on it!

While this may not sound like much to most modern gamers, for a pixel-based game, the way this is handled is extremely impressive, and adds a clever illusion of 3D with a very nice shadow system. Even some of the world textures are crafted with certain curves around the edges and changes of width that add a realistic sense of direction and angle. This is most visible in the game's own main menu, with the stone-brick wall trim which boxes us in the game's window.

The game currently is still in a very early alpha stage and offers no enemies or immediate dangers beyond the starvation of your villagers who wander around aimlessly like hilarious morons until you lay out the foundation for a town hall and send out vague and indirect orders for different resources - a feature true to its own advertisement. This game is definitely no standard RTS, as you have much less control over what happens within the world, instead treating the villagers like ants in an antfarm. You give them basic instructions and a general goal in life, and they immediately begin deciding amongst themselves who works where and who gathers or builds what.

Villagers marry and house themselves independently (assuming there had already been homes built, by your command) and have their own unique set of attributes such as Strength and Dexterity, which increase depending on how hard they work or how long they travel. If they are over-worked or if a spouse dies, a villager will become extremely depressed, and lose the will and the energy to continue working at full capacity for a short period of time. Eventually, the villager will find relief in rest or another lover, and so will continue on with his or her life.

The lack of direct control over your villagers is a very welcome and unique change of flow from your average city-building sim, as it gives you a very relaxed and non-competitive or war-driven experience. While I'm sure more threats will be introduced further down the line, the general concept of the game so far is very interesting and humble. I personally have never seen a game concept quite like this, and despite my lack of interest in pixel-based games, I found this quite enjoyable. Even with its current lack of content.

This is still a very early build, with a lot of features and content to be added as time goes by. As for right now though, in the state it's in at the time, it comes with a refreshing breath of life in the world of sandbox sims.  Where other games force linear and challenging objectives  or goals, this game's only real objective is survival, and determining how to best accomplish this, with strategy. The gameplay itself reminds me somewhat of Lemmings and Black & White, two gems from Lionhead Studios and Team17. One an objective-based RTS sim where you give general orders to minions in order to help them escape a maze, and the other a god-game where you do your best to keep a strong and stable economy and gain control over other villages. All in all, Retro-Pixel Castles comes with an /exceptionally/ nice soundtrack which really helps set the mood and clear the mind, and a surprising amount of detail and clarity in its world textures which promises a great deal of polish in the final product. The lighting and 3D-like illusions shown in 2D textures makes the game almost remind me a little of Don't Starve, with its ability to turn a simple 2D world into something more like a pop-out storybook. To know that all this comes from such a small dev team is very thrilling, and I would definitely like to see what direction this project takes in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being a fan of Dungeon Keeper and resource-gathering and structure-building games like Startopia, let's just say I really wanted to love this game. I don't even like it.

There's just not much game here. All buildings seem to be lackluster and blatantly 2-tier right up front. Little is hidden. Want wood? Lumber jack or advanced lumberjack. Want stone? mason or advanced Mason. The buildings are rather bland and show little innovation or setting/theme.

Basically you set your people to work by painting resource gathering areas on trees, stone, etc. Then you construct buildings to process these resources so you can make a defense tower or two and some magic makers.

You have a set of spells, once again all presented up front with little in the way of unlocking or earning their acquisition. Fireball for killing. Healing aura for ... healing. You can guess the rest. You've seen them in just about every other god-game.

My point is, re-hashing all the tired old god-game concepts from the 90's to now in a cute little pixel style doesn't show much originality and doesn't necessarily make the game fun. Grinding through several hours of this in attempt to enjoy it I finally realized, this simply is not a fun game yet.

I hope, sincerely, to update this review later upon release, praising it for it's clever spell set, tiered growth and scaling, intense combat mechanics creative buildings, hearty and lore-filled setting and my attachment to the characters I'm leading. Right now it just has none of these features.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is very good, and shows a lot of potential. However, it IS an Early Access game, and there are of course some issues in gameplay balance and other areas, namely in how unreasonably difficult the game can be to control. The 2 games I can most relate to are Banished, and Dwarf Fortress - though it clearly distinguishes itself from both of these.

The game itself is very challenging on its own terms, in a way that inspires you to continue learning and strategizing despite many failed attempts. The gameplay is very fluid (though the framerate sometimes isn't) and is structured very intuitively.
My other thoughts on this game so far are as follows:

+I love what there is of the soundtrack so far, somewhat reminds me of Runescape.
+Love the interactive Main menu
+The visuals of the game are so crisp and well designed, but I wish you could zoom out a little more, and zooming in as much as is available just hurts my eyes.
+Lots of variety in maps so far, but I wonder if there will be more - or even procedural generation.
+The map editor is excellent.
-----------
-It would make sense to lower temperature in rain and at night, and to let seasons affect gameplay differently depending on the area climate (ex. summer is hotter in the desert, not as bad in the tundra or mild areas)
-The villager info panel needs to be better. When looking at the only panel that lists all villagers, I can't tell hardly anything about any of them besides their level. Seeing any other information about them on that panel would be incrediblly useful, as would be the ability to sort them differently or click their names as links in alerts.
-Children (though they are agood game mechanic) currently make understanding your population difficult.
-Some god powers are difficult and/or confusing to use.
-It is very difficult and frustrating to attempt to navigate combat, or any other situation where a large amount of villagers and/or other creatures are stacked on top of one another - it's so hard to have an actual grasp on how the fighting is going, or if a villager needs healing because you it's so difficult to select them in the chaos.
-I really wish I there was an option to disable the screen shaking so constantly.
-----------
That's all I've thought up for now, but I'll try and keep this relatively updated.

This is the perfect game for relaxation. Just see how your villagers work by themselves, listen to the gorgeus music, watch the beatiful drawn map... Or, you can play in survival mode and focus on zombies not getting to your village!

Also, you have access to updates, with a lot of content in each of them. That's what I love of the game. I can be playing hours and hours without getting bored, and because of the updates, I get to play with new features.

Another thing I love about the game, is the game modes: skirmish and world map. You can play the classic skirmish, where you play in one map, or you can play in the world map, where you get access to a world with different maps. In world map mode, you have access to the limbo, where you can store villagers and resources. The game also features a tip system, magic towers, resource gathering... I guarantee you won't get bored with this game, and I recommend buying it. You should also buy the soundtrack. It's fantastic.

It's a real-time strategy game, all about building a village that will survive the onslaught of zombies, skeletons, and slimes. Unfortunately, after the update InDev 12, my graphics chip could no longer support the game. I'd try starting it up and it crashed time and time again.
Fast forward a few months, I get a different computer and a new nVidia graphics card. I realize that I can run the game, and am quick to download and play it. I come back to InDev 14, and wow was it a joy.

I essentially rediscovered the game, and so much had changed and been added to the development, that I was playing a very fresh game. I think that the fun of watching the game grow has been the best part of Retro-Pixel Castles so far, because it is a good game, and it has a lot of potential that I'm seeing put to use. This is worth the Early Access, indefinitely.

This game is beautiful both mechanically and aesthetically, but at this point it is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hard. As soon as you start getting your perfect setup of buildings, you start to get ♥♥♥♥♥. I've only gotten to day 11, and thats with my last villager running with a couple hords gathered behind him. At about day 7, hordes of monsters will start to appear and there is no chance of survival. Its just depressing when you see them come in and hear the repeated sounds of slaughter. Even with three fire bolt towers constantly fueled at both of my entry points, monsters would still get through or just cause a massive heap of blood and flames that would consume anything that gets in it. It really sucks :( I know that its still in development, and I'm really excited for all of the stuff thats in the drawing board, but seriously this game becomes very frustrating at a certain point because there is nothing you can do about your villagers being brutally ♥♥♥♥♥ by the evil masses.

Some suggestions:

Building priority - some way to make sure that villagers will actually build the structures they set up. I've gotten very fed up with how they'll drop all the resources at the buliding, but then just forget about it even though its the only thing queued up to build. So a firebolt tower might be fully set with resources but won't actually be usable for a whole day or two because the villagers get distracted. Maybe make sure that as soon as the last one drops resources on the building, he starts to work on it.

Specific land motivation - instead of just motivating the land in a general circle, maybe motivate certain resources. Its annoying having to either destroy or wait for my villagers to eventually chop down all the trees around small patches of food that I want to expand. If you try to expand without doing this, the forested area will just overrun the food, making it useless.

Healing aura towers - monsters are quite overpowered and they outnumber your villagers easily. It'd be nice to have a slight but steady flow of health to them in certain areas. So you could set up a couple towers near the points of regular conflict and it would give them a little flow of health. This, or just making the healing aura more powerful would work. After about day 8 you need to drop a minimum of two healing auras to even make a dent in the damage that monsters do to your villagers. Thus using up a lot of your influence.

Differentiating between friendlies and enemy health - maybe its just me, because i'm slightly colorblind, but I have a hard time telling the difference between the health bars when theres one of those massive heaps of blood and fire. It'd be cool if the health bars were drastically different in the color, or if a colorblind mode was added so you could have complementary colors, making them complete opposites.

In conclusion, this game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. When you get that flow of essence to your cullis gate, essence collectors, and firebolt towers... it just feels and looks amazing because theres all this power cycling through the map. Its a great way to show how everything is being fueled and refueled. After a successful night without any casualties, you feel like you did your godly job well. But its hard to get that job done because the people you rule are morons. Nevertheless, I would definitely recommend getting this game just so you can master your setup and understand whats most important. That way, once the devs to add in more complicated mechanics, you'll have all the basics completely down. Otherwise you'll just be thrown in later on with a LOT to learn.

9001/10 stars.

Early Access Review

I *love* citybuilders and population managers. I think Gnomoria and Banished are two of my most played games on Steam with about 60 and 30 hours respectively. I put about 40 hours into Dwarf Fortress, and quite enjoyed it. While RPC desperately wants to be like these titles, it is very far off - in a bad way.

First thing everybody should know is that there is no below-ground mining. Your world consists of a small-ish 'asteroid' that is one layer of ground thick, floating in space. There are frequent areas of the map that are just 'holes' where you can see the space behind the one-layer thick ground. I am certain that this strange mechanism is a result of limited money/resources/programming ability (idk), and was not intended. The allure of the games cited as inspiration (listed in first paragraph) was largely because you could take 'stuff' out of the ground and organize it above ground! When you take that away, I am significantly less interested.

You cannot rotate buildings because it would take too much effort to redraw the images. I get it - prioritize developement, but this is something very basic that needs to be mentioned. It further hints at where this game is going. I would imagine these images could be done in a long weekend, am I right? I am not trying to be harsh, but potential buyers need to be aware of these things.

These are the main two issues I have but there are a myriad of others such as map and individual person custimazation that I will not go into fully.There are also very few buildings at this point. Otherwise the music is quite good, and the artwork is pretty cool. This game probably was released on Early Access a bit too early. I got it for half price, and am fine with it because I want to try any and all citybuilders/population managers.

To my Steam friends: if you haven't played Gnomoria or Banished yet, go for those! If you are like me and have exhausted those, this *might* quench your thirst for a bit.

I don't believe any of the issues I put forth will be resolved (I mean its one guy working on this), but if they are, I will alter my review. Thanks for reading,

-Ryan

RPC has a very easy-to-use interface, little villagers that have personality in the way they wander around, and a game dev that is always open to hear ideas.

One thing I really like about the gameplay is that building is semi-automated, there's none of the worker micro-managing, when you place down a building you want made the workers get to work. As many have said, it's like playing with an ant colony.

Another important features is that it's survival-like. You have to feed and protect your people, they don't just wander off to another settlement like SimCity, you have to be responsible for your population, if you let them die from your carelessness then you are a murderer!

Updates are pretty quick and contain a lot of zingy features and the developer has a bath tub of creative ideas for the future of RPC.

I know that this is Early Acces, but the game is in desperate need of content.
All there is right now is three different resources, with their respective extractors and refinements, houses and towers. To be a village sim you might need a little more than that, honestly.

You are constantly attacked by monsters, day and night, without breaks. You can't tell your villagers to defend, you can only build towers (that are inadequate for the amount of monsters you receive), and hope for some villager to try and defend and not die. Because if they die, the only way to have another villager is to give free time (aka, stop building your village defenses) to your workers and wait a loooong time before a new one is born, while in the mean time you have less defenses and even more monsters.

The AI is very lackluster: building two or more buildings at a time really confuse builders, with the end result of having both of them unfinished for minutes. Gathering resource is dumb too, with villagers going for random sources instead of the nearest ones. Attacking enemies seems random too, with villagers attacking once, then starting to flee, then attacking again, then fleeing in the middle of other enemies, then dying.

On the art side of things: the graphics and UI are gorgeous. The sound track is quite good, although it isn't contextual: you can have an happy and reassuring track while the village is getting slaughtered. Particle effects are really cool and really add a lot to the presentation of the game.

For now I absolutely cannot recommend this game in the current state. I hope new content and new mechanics will be added to the game and the AI refined, so that this game will actually be about managing your village, not an endless cycle of building and rebuilding towers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Retro-Pixel Castles is an interesting game that seems to show great promise.

How would I describe the game? I guess I would say that it's something of a god-sim mixed with a city-building sim. Nothing too outside the box, generally speaking.

What else can I really say? My little men and women run about the world, mating and harvesting and mating some more (and stopping to chat all the damn time), and I continue to direct them to build stone walls, fire towers, and refining facilities. There's not much more to it at this point. However, that's due to the fact that the game is still in early access rather than any lack of vision on the part of the developers. I can see that there is a lot of room to grow in Retro-Pixel Castles and I have high hopes that the devs will continue to utilize that space.

The tutorials cover most everything you will need to know (not everything, of course, but they're tutorials - not strategy guides. I feel like there should be some information left to the player to discover). It's not difficult to figure out how to get a thriving community up and running once you understand the basic build order.

I guess that would be one of my main complaints about the game (and there aren't too many complaints I could actually list - see the end of the review for my short list): once you understand the basic build order of the game there isn't very much in the way of challenge with attaining a thriving community. It seems like the game is, so far, simple and easy. This can be changed further on in development, and I feel like with the addition of more content the challenge rating should rise decently.

Since pro/con lists seem to be all the rage in reviews, I will use one now. This list is not exhaustive.

Pros:
+Easy to learn mechanics
+Enjoyable and open-ended simulation
+Pleasing graphical elements
+Entertaining gameplay

Cons:
-Soundtrack gets repetitive
-It can be a bit of a hassle figuring out which unit is your villager and which is the monster in a large melee
-Small amount of content at this point
-Lack of effective late-game purpose (once I've built all the buildings and made my havens safe for my townsfolk there isn't any reason to continue except to raise a large population in order to populate more areas of the map)

I want to make a note that I feel like all of the cons so listed are easily fixed and I have a good feeling that the devs are either currently working towards those goals or will soon begin to do so.

I won't waste any time attempting to offer my thoughts as to how to fix said cons - this is simply a review.

Anyway, without going on too long (too late) I would have to say this: if you're a fan of god sims or city building sims then you should definitely keep an eye on this game. With a few more updates I think it could easily become a mainstay of your gaming repertoire. With a full complement of content I feel that Retro-Pixel Castles could be something great.
